terms.definition: A system that tracks and manages changes to documents over time, allowing users to access previous versions and maintain an audit trail of revisions.
A feature that allows multiple users to work on the same document simultaneously in real-time, enabling team members to make edits and add comments together.
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems.
Application Programming Interface - a set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate and share data with each other.
Return on Investment - a financial metric used to measure the efficiency and profitability of an investment relative to its cost.
Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a provider and accessed by users over the internet.
Connections between different software tools and platforms that allow them to work together and share data seamlessly.
Data collection and analysis features that provide metrics on user engagement, document usage, and performance to help optimize documentation.
The ability to customize a platform's appearance with an organization's logos, colors, and style guidelines to maintain brand consistency.
A chronological record of all changes and activities performed on documents, providing transparency and accountability for modifications.
A lightweight markup language that uses simple text formatting syntax to create structured documents that can be converted to HTML.
Step-by-step instructional documents that help users understand how to use a product, service, or system effectively.
Frequently Asked Questions - a compilation of common questions and their answers about a product, service, or topic.
External software applications or services developed by companies other than the primary platform provider, often integrated to extend functionality.
Personalized web addresses that organizations can use instead of default platform URLs to maintain their brand identity and professional appearance.
